title: Cloud Computing Essentials

lesson.title: What is Web Development?
lesson.content: Web development refers to the process of building and maintaining websites. It encompasses a variety of tasks and skills, including web design, content creation, client-side and server-side scripting, and network security configuration. Websites can range from simple static pages to complex web applications, online stores, and social media platforms. Web development is categorized into three main types: front-end development, which deals with the user-facing part of a website; back-end development, which handles server-side functionality and databases; and full-stack development, which combines both. This lesson will cover the role of a web developer, tools used in the field, and the evolution of web development from simple HTML pages to modern frameworks like React and Angular.

lesson.title: Understanding the Web: How It Works
lesson.content: The web operates through a network of interconnected computers and servers that communicate using protocols like HTTP and HTTPS. A website is hosted on a server, and users access it using a browser on their computer or mobile device. When you enter a URL into your browser, it sends a request to a server. The server processes the request and sends back the required resources, such as HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files, which your browser uses to display the website. This lesson will delve into concepts such as DNS, IP addresses, and the client-server model. You will also learn about different types of websites, including static, dynamic, and single-page applications, and how they are structured.

lesson.title: Introduction to HTML: The Structure of the Web
lesson.content: HTML, or HyperText Markup Language, is the backbone of all websites. It provides the structure and layout of web pages by using elements like headings, paragraphs, images, links, and lists. In this lesson, we will cover the basic syntax of HTML, including tags, attributes, and nesting elements. You'll learn how to create a simple web page with a title, headings, paragraphs, and images. Additionally, we will explore semantic HTML, which helps improve accessibility and SEO by using meaningful tags like <header>, <main>, and <footer>. By the end of this lesson, you will have a solid foundation in creating well-structured HTML documents.

lesson.title: Styling with CSS: Making Your Website Beautiful
lesson.content: CSS, or Cascading Style Sheets, is used to style and design web pages. It allows you to control the color, layout, fonts, and overall appearance of your website. In this lesson, we will cover the basics of CSS, including selectors, properties, and values. You will learn how to apply styles directly within HTML using inline styles, embed them in the <style> tag, or use external CSS files for better organization. We'll also discuss the box model, which defines how elements are sized and spaced, and introduce responsive design concepts using media queries. Practical examples will include creating layouts, styling buttons, and adding hover effects.

lesson.title: JavaScript Basics: Adding Interactivity to Your Website
lesson.content: JavaScript is a versatile programming language that enables you to add interactivity and dynamic behavior to your website. From simple tasks like form validation and dropdown menus to complex web applications, JavaScript powers it all. This lesson will introduce the fundamentals of JavaScript, including variables, data types, operators, functions, and events. You will learn how to write basic scripts, manipulate the Document Object Model (DOM), and respond to user interactions. We will also touch on best practices, such as debugging and structuring your code for readability. By the end of this lesson, you will be able to create interactive web elements like image sliders and modal pop-ups.

lesson.title: Introduction to Version Control with Git
lesson.content: Version control is a critical skill for any web developer. It allows you to track changes to your code, collaborate with others, and revert to previous versions if necessary. Git is the most widely used version control system, and platforms like GitHub provide a collaborative environment for developers. In this lesson, we will cover the basics of Git, including initializing repositories, committing changes, and branching. You'll learn common Git commands like "git add," "git commit," and "git push." We'll also demonstrate how to use GitHub to host your projects, create pull requests, and resolve merge conflicts. By the end of this lesson, you will be comfortable managing your code using Git and collaborating with other developers.

lesson.title: Introduction to Responsive Web Design
lesson.content: With the increasing use of mobile devices, responsive web design has become essential. Responsive design ensures that your website looks and works well on screens of all sizes, from desktops to smartphones. In this lesson, we will explore the principles of responsive design, including flexible layouts, fluid grids, and media queries. You will learn how to use CSS frameworks like Bootstrap or TailwindCSS to create responsive designs quickly. We'll also discuss mobile-first design strategies and test your website on various devices and screen resolutions. Practical exercises will include creating a responsive navigation bar and optimizing images for different screen sizes.

lesson.title: Hosting Your First Website
lesson.content: Hosting your website is the final step in making it accessible to the world. This lesson will guide you through the process of choosing a hosting provider, purchasing a domain name, and deploying your website. We will discuss the differences between shared hosting, VPS hosting, and cloud hosting, and introduce platforms like Netlify and Vercel for modern web developers. You'll also learn about FTP, SSH, and other tools for uploading your files to the server. Additionally, we will cover basic website optimization techniques to improve load times and ensure reliability. By the end of this lesson, you will have your website live on the internet.
